title: Ticket #7143: Daemons slow to respond to commands on Windows
description:
A support customer reports that after a period of time running, their Schedd will become slow to respond to commands even when it is not otherwise very busy.

Much investigation lead to the fact that the Daemon command pump was getting into a state where an attempt to hand off a socket from shared port was not waking up the pump. The socket handoff would complete only once select timed out in the pump. Once the Schedd got into this state, socket handoff in the pump would always happen only when select woke up for some other reason. The Wake_up_select mechanism had simply stopped working.

This is exemplified by the following log snippits

The core of this bug is a race between DaemonCore::Driver() and SharedEndPoint::PipeListenerThread() operating on the DaemonCore variables async_pipe and async_pipe_signal. PipeListenerThread() calls DaemonCore::Register_PumpWork_TS() and none of the functions in this call stack grab a lock for operating on these variables. Certain interleavings of the of the instructions in the two threads can result in async_pipe_signal set to true and the async_pipe connection empty. This condition is never cleared.

The main fix is to unconditionally set async_pipe_signal to false in DaemonCore::Driver() on windows (this is already the behavior on unix). This clears the bad state if the daemon gets into it. We also add usage of InterlockedExchange() when modifying async_pipe_signal reduce risks from cache incoherency. All other changes in this ticket are error detection and reporting.
